Real estate investment trusts are pools of investor-backed cash that purchase real estate. While pension funds routinely invest in both REITs and private equity real estate, it is extremely uncommon to have a pension effectively do a bailout of a fund facing massive redemption requests.

Blackstone‚Äôs BREIT differs substantially from the $1.3 trillion real estate investment trust, or REIT, market. Nearly all REITs are publicly traded, which means that investors can cash out their money at will. This is not the case with BREIT, which allows Blackstone to suspend redemptions.

, Blackstone spokesman Jeffrey Kauth noted in an email that ‚ÄúBREIT is not a mutual fund and has never gated. It is a semi-liquid product and is working exactly as planned.‚Äù ‚ÄúGating‚Äù refers to a practice by hedge funds and private equity where redemptions are entirely blocked, as opposed to just partially blocked, like with BREIT.
Blackstone is the largest private landlord in the country,

300,000 units across the United States. In California alone, Blackstone and its affiliates, including BREIT, own at least 9,000 housing units, including concentrations in San Diego, Los Angeles, Sacramento, and the Bay Area, according to research done by the Private Equity Stakeholder Project.

Those units tend to be located in lower-income census tracts, where on average residents make roughly 25 percent less than the state‚Äôs median household income. Escalating housing costs are integral to Blackstone‚Äôs business strategy. ‚ÄúOur major concern with Blackstone is that this is a company whose model for making money for investors is to buy up rental properties and raise the rent,‚Äù said Lybarger at AFSCME.

‚ÄúWe believe we have the most favorable resident policies among any large landlord in the U.S., including not making a single non-payment eviction for over two years during COVID,‚Äù noted Kauth in his email.‚ÄúWe operate in accordance with California‚Äôs rent stabilization laws and are investing $100 million to make these communities better places to live.‚Äù
But some BREIT tenants say that if anything, the trust‚Äôs massive foray into housing has been anything but beneficial.

One tenant, Michael McBride, says that since BREIT purchased his apartment complex in Chula Vista outside of San Diego a couple of years ago, basic maintenance has fallen by the wayside. It took ‚Äúat least‚Äù a month for BREIT to fix the heat in his apartment after he had complained about it in winter.

‚ÄúI just got heat inside my apartment,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNow my front room thermostat is not working, and we‚Äôre having water issues ‚Äî it smells like bleach. Something needs to be done.‚Äù BREIT currently owns 66 apartment buildings in San Diego County.

BREIT‚Äôs approach has lately faced turbulence. Because the fund is substantially indebted ‚Äì it carries $90 billion in debt on $140 billion in total assets ‚Äî even small downturns like the recent economic decline put the fund in jeopardy, since both gains and losses are magnified because of high leverage.
What‚Äôs more, BREIT has a small but significant portion of its holdings in the office and retail sector, which have been battered in the post-pandemic economy.
, a separate Blackstone entity sold two office towers in Orange County, California, for 36 percent less than it paid for them nine years ago.

Multifamily housing like that owned by BREIT has also faced headwinds as the Federal Reserve has repeatedly raised interest rates, which make it more difficult for potential buyers ‚Äî typically other real estate investment trusts or private equity firms ‚Äî to purchase housing. Sales of apartment buildings fell by two-thirds in the most recent quarter,
to data from the CoStar Group.
Such upheaval has led many BREIT investors to get cold feet. In March, BREIT received $4.5 billion in redemption requests, but only fulfilled $666 million of them.

it was investing $4.5 billion in the struggling fund ‚Äî which in effect allows it to start refunding other investors‚Äô money.

UC‚Äôs pension system is fairly unique in that workers have no power over how investment decisions are made. All decisions are made by the regents, which are appointed by the California governor for 12-year terms.

in a Blackstone press release, ‚ÄúThis type of large, opportunistic investment effectively leverages the UC‚Äôs more than $150 billion portfolio to benefit the 600,000 students, faculty, staff, and pensioners from our 10 campuses and six academic health centers.‚Äù

Likewise, the university‚Äôs endowment fund would have an additional $6.4 billion in its coffers, or 36 percent increase of its current value.
